data.title: John Denver's Guitars?
data.meta_description: Can someone direct me to information about John Denver's guitars? What did he play - on which songs? Thanks.
data.text:
Same with me, and those Guild jumbo 12-ers have a wonderfully shimmery tone. I love 'em. Those are the only other acoustic 12-ers that I like, Martin 12-ers being my absolute dream gits.

Samilyn, I have to agree with you. But, have you ever played one of the old Framus (German made) 12-Strings. I had two of them back in the day. The first one (tobacco burst) was in a soft gig bag when I slipped on some ice carrying it and put my right elbow right through the back of it. The second one was the Framus Texan, spruce and rosewood. Dynamite sound......really honked.......had a narrow neck, too, like a standard 6 string........1 11/16" I believe. Framus is out of business, but if not, I'd own one today. Sold my Texan back in '82 and have been kicking myself every day since. Don't have a picture to send you, but "Google Images" shows several Texans if you care to see one. BTW- The Texan, at the Army PX in 1968 cost me a whopping $92. And, the molded case for it was an additional $8. Try THAT today!! I sold it, 14 years later for a LOT more than that.

Samilyn, I have to agree with you. But, have you ever played one of the old Framus (German made) 12-Strings. I had two of them back in the day. The first one (tobacco burst) was in a soft gig bag when I slipped on some ice carrying it and put my right elbow right through the back of it. The second one was the Framus Texan, spruce and rosewood. Dynamite sound......really honked.......had a narrow neck, too, like a standard 6 string........1 11/16" I believe. Framus is out of business, but if not, I'd own one today. Sold my Texan back in '82 and have been kicking myself every day since. Don't have a picture to send you, but "Google Images" shows several Texans if you care to see one. BTW- The Texan, at the Army PX in 1968 cost me a whopping $92. And, the molded case for it was an additional $8. Try THAT today!! I sold it, 14 years later for a LOT more than that.

Wow, Opa...those sound like some great gits.

Oh, man, sorry to hear about the elbow incident. That must have been heartbreaking.

No, I've never gotten to play a Framus, nor even seen anything other than a pic of one. Yup - just googled and the Texan is one cool looking git.

Pity there's too few of those wonderful old gits around. Nothing in the world like vintage tone, eh?

Just wanted to say how much I love JDs first few albums.

Rocky Mountain High, Take Me To Tomorrow and Whose Garden Was This are all excellent albums. It's a shame he's better know here in the UK for his later work with Olivia Newton John and...erm...the Muppets!

Anyone know if John played all the guitar parts on those albums? There's some really nice lines in e.g. Rocky Mountain High or Prisoners that I aspire to being able to play. Can't ever find good tabs for the early songs though, and I'm not skilled enough to work them out.

Did he play mainly in dropped D? Sounds like DADGBD on Prisoners...is that right?

I should add... when John passed away, I was getting about 180 e-mails per hour from JD fans around the world. I wrote a song in 1991 called "The Bard" and it was actually about John and his music. We had the same record producer for a time. John's music always meant so much to me, still does. So, I wrote the song... here are the lyrics:

There was an old man

was a teller of stories

of visions of lands far away

His stories were songs

from a lifetime of living

things he had seen in his day.

This man, he had wisdom

from years he was living

his insights outnumbered his days

His songs, you could say,

they were much more than stories

they helped us to see on our way

Chorus

The Bard, the dreamer, the singer of songs

about treasures far better than gold

Free for the taking for all, so we are told

The Bard, the dreamer the lover of children

and all who are willing to give

The Bard sang songs about life, and how we should live

The children they sat

at the feet of the minstrel

His songs filled them all with delight

and the Bard he adored them,

he loved little children

they were precious, indeed, in his sight

He would sing them his songs

about magical kingdoms

where good would prevail in the end

He would sing about castles

knights in bright armor

defenders of truth and of men.

Chorus

Then One night it ended

the Bard he was gone

like a night mist, the wind blows away

But his message lives on

in the songs that he gave us

and still helps us see on our way

chorus (x2)

----------note, I wrote this as if John was the minstrel teaching songs about life, just as the lyrics imply. The knight metaphor is really a hero to those that love the land and the wisdom of his message. The children are like those of Rhymes and Reasons. The people only understood the message after the bard was gone, but, the message lives on... it was John's legacy.

Thanks so much to all the JD fans who replied to my query. Appreciate very much the info you all provided about JD's guitars. I have a pic of him on the cover of one songbook with a steel guitar - anyone know what guitar that was and which songs were played on that instrument?

FYI - I have been a long-time fan of the man and his music and have sung his tunes around the house (sometimes to my son's exasperation - generational thing) and am now learning to play on the guitar to accompany. I was in CA at the time of John's death (I lived and worked in the bay area) and went to the very moving candlelit ceremony in October, 1997 in Pacific Grove (near where his plane crashed) in memorium. It was hard to imagine that he would no longer sing those songs. Hope this isn't TMI - but thought I owed an explanation for the questions about his guitars - trying to find some of his sound again.
